title: I recently received a Notice of Involuntary Lien Recorded with the office of the San Bernardino county recorder office.
question: I co-own a house with my brother. What will happen to our house. Can they force us out, force us to sell our what can they do with this lean? Please help.
answers:
It means there is a judgment entered against you somewhere and they have now recorded it in San Bernardino County. Most likely, it will stay there until you sell, refinance or die. The likelihood of foreclosure or taking other actions against your house depends on how much money is at stake, the equity you have in your house, etc.

A court order would normally be required to force the sale of your house, as your share of the equity is considered exempt, by your living there. I agree with my colleague that it appears this may be a judgment against you and that if you were not properly served, you should have an experienced debt collection DEFENSE attorney help determine your next steps to deal with that judgment, so that the threat of the home being sold is reduced or eliminated.

This is the sort of lien that could also survive bankruptcy, if you have any equity in your house, unless the judgment is first set aside. My web site and blog have a wealth of information about your options and default judgments.

If you received a Notice of Involuntary Lien, it most like is because there has been a judgment entered against either you and..or your brother. Recording an Abstract of Judgment puts a lien on any real property in your name.

Your question does not indicate whether either you or your brother were aware of a lawsuit resulting in a judgment against either of you. If the answer is no, then you need to hire an attorney to set aside the default and vacate default judgment so that you can respond to the lawsuit.

If you were aware of the lawsuit and resulting judgment, then you should know that the lien in itself will need to be paid off or otherwise satisfied if and when you either sell the house or refinance. Because judgments in California accrue 10% post judgment interest, it is possible, but rare, that the judgment creditor will force the sale of the house to get paid.
